manifests/profile/base/metrics/collectd/.message:
Would be good to trigger a check on the sudo syntax here, especially since it's something an operator can provide.
This can be done with the following "exec":

  exec {"sudo-syntax-check for file ${dname}":
    command     => "visudo -c -f '/etc/sudoers.d/${dname}' || ( rm -f '/etc/sudoers.d/${dname}' && exit 1)",
    refreshonly => true,
  }

It can be triggered via a "notify" from the "file" resource bellow.

This ensures we don't have any broken sudoers content - having such broken content will break the whole sudo, and is pretty bad, as you can imagine
as an alternative we probably could as well use the rootwrap tooling?

@Bogdan is it still alive? And not sure if it's the right tool here, since rootwrap is more about filtering things based on known patterns. Apparently, there is no known patterns when it comes to sensu|collectd :/. Unless I've missed the point with rootwrap..

IIUC using rootwrap would mean that operator needs to be aware of correct configuration of the rootwrap and during implementation of his availability checks he/she would have to use "sudo nova-rootwrap /path/to/config/generated/by/tripleo's/puppet/or/ansible the-command" instead of just "sudo the-command" every time he/she needs to use sudo. I would say please let's not over-engineer this feature now and implement this atrocity only in case some security engineer will start running in circles and screaming "sercurity hole" :).
would notifying a refresh-only resource ever work?
yes. this is the way puppet works and provides "handlers".
This directory isn't bind mounted from the host, so how is going to be stored in the collectd config_volume and then exposed to the collectd container at step 5 later?

neutron_lib/services/qos/base.py.message: I was hesitating if this should be validate_rule_for_port or validate_policy_for_port. Let me know if you consider policy the better choice.
The first one, IMO, because this is what you are doing (actually you are passing the rule, not the whole policy).

What I was trying to ask is this:

Do we ever want to support the case where a policy needs to be validated as a whole (for example because its rules may interfere with each other), so the validity of the whole policy cannot be ANDed from the validity of its rules?

If not, validate_RULE_for_port is okay as is.

If yes, we may want to extend this API with validate_POLICY_for_port and change the neutron patch accordingly.
Hmmmm, are we going to raise an exception by default? I think this method is going to return true or false.

The QoS driver is going to call this method in drivers supporting some rules (LB supports all of them) but without this method defined.

By default, this should return True.

releasenotes/notes/link-amphora-to-loadb.message:
It really wasn't the end of the process, it was just seven steps farther down the flow where we associate the booted amphora to the load balancer and mark the amphora as "allocated".
Basically, before this, we made sure the amphora was functional prior to tying it to the load balancer.
https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/_images/LoadBalancerFlows-get_create_load_balancer_flow.svg

I would argue that the amphora still *belongs* to the loadbalancer during the create process, even if it's not ready yet (or even if it fails).

Yeah, it's in the ``nova_api`` DB. Over time the extra specs table will gradually be weakened and eventually removed.

For example, to create a server through Horizon, the booting server selects the image, flavor, and network configuration. If your server needs to specify some flavor group metadata (extra specs), you need to select the favor group metadata as the VM's creation parameter.

If your flavor group metadata is not None, the selected flavor_group will be recorded in the instance_extra (removing flavor_group_instance_association, adding flavor_group to instanceExtra) table.

I was looking for what the short and long-term upgrade path looks like for operators. Do they hand-copy all the extra_specs into flavor_groups when U is released? How do they know when to remove the extra_specs from their flavors? Do we copy that stuff for them somehow? Does the API work in the meantime?

AFAICT, you're proposing splitting out the "hairy details" from the "simple details" of a given hardware configuration. The questionable legitimacy of that goal aside, the "hairy details" are not "flavor groups" by any stretch, AFAICT.

> No association of flavor and flavor groups.

There *must* be some way to map flavors with these "flavor groups", IMHO. Going from what we have now to allowing people to boot guests that have tiny CPU and RAM, but expensive attributes like GPUs is not an option. If operators want to opt into that "anything can be mixed with anything else" behavior, that's fine, but we cannot remove the ability to limit that composition.

When booting an instance, like selecting image and network, select a flavor group and record the flavor group in the ``instance_extra`` table.
When multiple different flavor groups are selected, the server is combined according to the attributes of the flavor group.

So you will do this composition in the api and return a 400 to the user if they combine anything that conflicts? What happens if two groups combine to create something that the virt driver cannot possibly provide? Like some combination of hugepages, pci devices, and disk cache mode or something? You can't determine that in the API, no keys technically conflicted, and the only option is to fail very late (and expensively) in the virt driver with an instance fault hopefully explaining the problem. That is not a good situation, IMHO. One reason/benefit of flavors being atomic (or at least cultivated by the admins) is that they are known-good configurations that can be booted on the virt driver(s) and hardware available in the cluster.

...or how flavors get associated with flavor groups. Surely you're not proposing allowing users to boot any flavor in combination with any arbitrary group(s) of extra_specs, right? There are a lot of scheduler filters that work based on the extra_specs. What changes will need to happen in the scheduler filter code?

I have many other issues with this spec, but this statement right here (which, yes, I summarized for you in the previous rev :)) is where we disagree. I don't agree that the templating is important, but I _strongly_ disagree that flavors and (what is now) extra_specs should be completely disjoint and compose-able with no affinity or restriction. Since today they are necessarily tightly bound, I will not support any proposal that breaks that in a way that operators cannot retain the current functionality and behavior.

> > I will not support any proposal that breaks that in a way
 > > that operators cannot retain the current functionality and
 > > behavior.
 > 
 > FWIW I've been assuming this would not replace extra specs, that
 > there would "never" be a requirement to migrate existing flavors to
 > use these flavor groups. Rather, it would just be an additional
 > option that operators could use if they chose and felt it was right
 > for their environment.

Well, Brin confirmed in his replies on the previous set that the goal here is to empty, and eventually remove extra_specs. So, keeping them would provide at least the ability to retain today's functionality.

 > Nevertheless, as mentioned elsewhere, the devil is in the details:
 > how to determine which components can or can't be composed together
 > for technical, resource, authorization, or just plain sensibility
 > reasons. Is there an overall yes/no policy switch allowing
 > composition? Are individual groups available to certain users? Are
 > groups "aggregated" somehow to signify which flavors and other
 > groups they can be composed with? Etc.

Indeed. Plus, if we gain this compose-able groups thing, plus have extra_specs on the flavor still, we need to have logic on how to handle conflicts, overrides, etc. And that needs to exist everywhere that flavors are currently handled in the code, which is...a lot of places.
i would expect that we woudl check for conflcit when associating the composable bits with the

> I will not support any proposal that breaks that in a way
 > that operators cannot retain the current functionality and
 > behavior.

FWIW I've been assuming this would not replace extra specs, that there would "never" be a requirement to migrate existing flavors to use these flavor groups. Rather, it would just be an additional option that operators could use if they chose and felt it was right for their environment.

Nevertheless, as mentioned elsewhere, the devil is in the details: how to determine which components can or can't be composed together for technical, resource, authorization, or just plain sensibility reasons. Is there an overall yes/no policy switch allowing composition? Are individual groups available to certain users? Are groups "aggregated" somehow to signify which flavors and other groups they can be composed with? Etc.

Answering all of these questions is possible, but will lead to a semantically complex solution by the time we're done. And as I said before, I'm not sure that complexity is worth the benefit gained.

metataday that affect resouce usage which typicly people want to charge more for e.g hw:cpu_policy=dedicated and metatadata that does not e.g. hw:pmu=true|false or hw:cpu_socket=2

this is problematic too as it will lead to a flvor_group explotion

you want a many to many relation ship or at a minium a many to 1 relation ship where the flaovr meta data group can be mapped to multiple flavors.


if we want to normalise the db, which i think we should,
instead of 1 table we shoudl add 3.

flavor_extra_spec_group_mappings with 3 colums flavor_id(int), instance_uuid(nullable),and extra_spec_group_id(int) that have the unique constraint shoudl be the triplet of all fields.

the second table the flavor_extra_specs_group
shoudl contain the id(int),uuid,create_at,updated_at,deleted_at,name and deleted fields

a third table extra_specs shoudl have an the following fields
flavor_group_id(int),key,value

on full delete(purge) of a flavor group row form the flavor_extra_specs_group table the delete shoudl cascade removing the flavor_extra_spec_group_mappings entry and the related rows.

im not actully conviced we need to soft delete this by the way i woudl prefer to delete the row when you delete the flavor group rather then have a deleted_at column and deleted filed.

by the way part of the reason im suggesting this is i think we shoudl use this for all flavours to store the metadata in a table so that we dont store it in a json blob in the db.

that woudl allow use to efficiently search for flavours based on metadata. even without the flavour groups concept i think there would be value in that.

In the latest patch (PS11), I will add anonther table to the DB, and I think there are two tables can achieve the desired function.

One table is "resources_metadata" to record the composable bits, as following fuelds.
  - id(int),create_at,updated_at,deleted_at, name, rules, description and deleted fields

Another table is "resources_metadata_mapping" to record the composable bits used by which instance, as following fields:
  - created_at, updated_at,deleted_at, id(int), resources_md_id, instance_uuid and deleted fields.

I dont think we need the flaovr_id in the "resources_metadata_mapping" table, because of the mnaser point, we can save the vcpu, ram and disk in a composable bit, at this point we don't need a flavor.

 > by the way part of the reason im suggesting this is i think we shoudl use this for all flavours to store the  metadata in a table so that we dont store it in a json blob in the db.

If we saved the metadata as key, value (not json blob), that maybe we should compose some of keys to support the server create, maybe that's not easy (such as disk_qos).
In other words, if we just have one key,value, we can save as json blob, it's just include a metadata.

 > that woudl allow use to efficiently search for flavours based on metadata. even without the flavour groups concept i think there would be value in that.

Review "resources_metadata" and "resources_metadata_mapping", we can search the resources metadata for an instance easily, if the instance composed by a base flavor and composable bits, we can from the instance get the flavor_id or the instance's all metadata.

the flavor id was in the flavor_extra_spec_group_mappings for a reason.

i did not want user to be able to apply flavor_extra_specs_group to any flavor.

so for a use to be able to apply a flavor_extra_specs_group to a flaovr i wanted to require that there must be a mapping
between the flavor and flavor_extra_specs_group with the instacne_uuid filed set to null.

i was also thinking we could extend mapping with 1 addtional filed which woudl indicate if flavor_extra_specs_group shoud be applied by default.

i left those out of my previous comments becaue i wanted to see your responces to some for the other comments i had first.

i think we need a way to restrict what flavour the flavor_extra_specs_group can be applied too and perhaps even want project can use them similar to the way favour access

i need to look at the latest version but with the breilf look i gave i dont think that is possible with the latest schema

as a side note we should consider deprecating these for removal.

the vif_qos item in partacalar should not be used any more and you should use neutron qos policies instead.

the cpu_limits dont actually server much use unless you hare heavily over subscribing a host. cpu_allocation_ratio>4

the disk qos is the only modertly useful one and even then if you are using cinder you should be using cinder qos instead.
its only really use is for non cinder volumes to limit the rbd or qcow backends. even then on the ceph side you can limit iops via ceph pool options so that just leaves qos of local storage which i dont think is often used.
Yeah, I will remove the vif qos note. I think the disk qos will still be used frequently in local storage, and we do have such customers (although a few), the cpu_limits also used by some customers.
these would be admin only by default correct.

As far as I understand the current proposal (or at least what we discussed at the PTG) to have ComposableFlavorProperty objects passed in the boot (and resize) request along with a Flavor and merge the Flavor and the ComposableFlavorProperty at the API level and then store the resulted new Flavor in the instance as if it were the requested flavor for this instance. This the GET /servers/{intance-uuid} response would return the merged flavor as a single entity as before.

Mnaser proposed during the PTG to allow composing vcpus, ram and disk as well. If this feels to big scope to start with then I think it is OK to start with the extra specs. I also agree to define precedence order. For me as the first step the rules would be the following:
* If a base flavor has an extra_spec key then it cannot be in any ComposableFalvorProperty in the same boot or resize request.
* If a ComposableFlavorProperty has an extra_spec key then no other ComposableFlavorProperty can have the same extra_spec key in the same boot or resize request
If the any of the rules are violated then HTTP 409.

ya that is kind of what i was thinking for the conflict rules. if we allow cpus,ram and disk to be overrides however it does not follow the rules as we are allowing the ComposableFalvorProperties to override the base flavour.

i could resolve that conflict in my head by saying the flavour values must be set to 0 or -1 to allow them to be set by the ComposableFalvorProperties in which case i think it could be self consistent for flavour resource and extra specs.
composed the ram, disk and vcpu will be not contained in this spec.

what is the rules filed.

i really dont want a flavor replacemnet spec to just tore the extra_specs as a json blob so if this is intended to hold the  extra specs that a hard -1 form me.

text fields are stored as seperate files on disk so in addtion to being very hard to work with if we just dump a dictonay of key values into it as json its also slow.

this is why i had 3 tables to normalise it and extract the key value data into a seperate table which is both faster to query and makes it much eaier to do thinks like find which

resources_metadata entries have a specify key/value set.

e.g. if i want to be able to query this api to determin what
ResourcesMetadata policy to apply to request hugepages it woudl be nice to be able to quickly list the ResourcesMetadata polices that have hw:mem_page_size defiend preferable with a value of large,2MB or 1G.

that way i dont need to query for the list of all policies and filter them client side.

Yeah, should add the flavor_id to this table, and I will change the ``resource_metadata`` table's model. Change the "name, rules" to "key/value" (from your suggestion in PS10).

In ``resource_metadata`` table, I want to define the "key" is unique, so if we need another value of the same "key", we need to update it firstly.

this is a case where i think it makes sense to think about the ablity to apply some metadta groups by default and how over rides would work.

so if we have the flavor_id in the mapping table and a default colum that woudl allow use to do two things

first we could define a low ios qos policy say 100 iops and we coulld map it to all our cheaper flavors and mark it as default.

we could then define a high iops resouce metadata group
map it to all a set of flavor and allow the user to opt into more iops potentially at a higher cost.

if instead of a boolean default colume we make it a enuma policy colume we could support default,requested,required policies default means it would be applied to the flavor without being requested on teh command line, requested means
it must be requested expcitly and reqire means if there is a conflcit the value for this resouce group is used.

this might be more complex then stictly nessisary but if this was to eventurally replace flavors i would want a richer way of grouping resouce metadata and flavor so that i could more essily express policy.
To limit the scope of the first step I would skip defaulting now. But later this could be an interesting step forward.

it think it would give an interesting way to quickly apply things to multiple flavours at once but keep a single point of control. but ya i would be ok with skiping the default/polices in v1 to limit scope.

this is the use case im least comfortable with.

we could do this but it has the highest chance to break expectation and workflows.

allowing resouce requst in general without a way to restict the resouce groups as i said above would allow you to request the cheapest/smallest flavor + a gpu or fpga which you have a limited amoutn of or other malicious requests that could stave the could of specific types of resources.

the defence against this currently is that the resource metadta polices would be create via the admin but it means if they ever create a policy for a gpu or cyborg reousce without a way to restic that resource metadata to a set of flavour you can prevent people abusing this or jsut requesting combination that cant work but that they dont know cant work since they dont understand your infrastructure.
i.e. you cant request hugpages for guest with memory that is not a multiple of 1G becuase you only use 1G hugepage in your cloud.
This side of the requested feature coming from mnaser, so it would be good if he could chime in. Personally I'm OK to drop this from the scope of the first implementation step.

-1 would likely be better as 0 because 0 is used for boot form volume but both would work.
the down side fo this is you need to create new flavors

which is why i originally wannted to use the mapping table to say which flaovr composible bits could be applied too.

then the admin can choose which flavor can have the cpus ram or disk altered without altering any existign flavors

the current proposal will change the existing data storage too because you will have to merged the extra specs form teh flavor with the new construct that are being added.

also this is in third normal form which will allow seach for resouce metadata polices/goups by key/value or searching for instance by key/value which could be quite useful for capacity or resource planning. this will also allow an efficent way to quickly and programticly select resouce groups based on there content without having to list all of them and parse the embeded json blob.

while this would chagne the database structure we could hide this in the model so we don't need any object changes and exsiting flavor api would not need to change.

sure but we don't need to store the key value pairs in a JSON blob to construct the same flavour object.

so all im suggesting is we handle this at the db object level and we make no changes to the ovo fields. by the time we have constructed the flavor ovo we shoudl have already done the merge.

for what its worth i did not  have the instance_uuid in this table wehn i proposed it for that reason since i wanted to store the merged version in the instance.

as a compromise can we keep this third table and just drop the instance filed to not store the 
ComposableFalvorProperties key value paris in a json blob.

each of the indvigual key value paris are metadata itme and the whole thing is a polcy or group.

neutron/tests/base.py.message:
question: It looks like _set_timeout() comes from oslotest.base[1]. This method just calls useFixture. I think it leads to set up fixtures multiple times. Does it work as expected?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslotest/blob/ff3cb9557158504c643f96aa50d03f58b5dae3fc/oslotest/base.py#L125-L129

Good question. I didn't see that.

oslotest.base.BaseTestCase._set_timeout is enabling the fixture oslotest.timeout.Timeout. This one is just a wrapper for fixtures.Timeout.

When calling a second time to use the timeout fixture, we are just adding another fixture to the test class. This second fixture will be cleaned up during the test case tear down. Both fixtures are independent instances.

But signal.alarm is a unique instance per process. If we reset the value of signal.signal [1], this will change the signal timeout for this process. But at this point the signal timeout was exhausted and setting it again will restart the countdown (exactly what we need).

Both timeout fixtures (if this line is called once), during the teardown will set the signal alarm to 0. Because this is an idempotent method, there is no problem.

[1] https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/blob/master/fixtures/_fixtures/timeout.py#L65
Thanks for clarification. It sounds fine.

kuryr_kubernetes/cni/binding/dpdk.py.message:
I’d like some input on this also. Right now the dpdk driver is hardcoded to uio_pci_generic, which is fine since it’s the one you need for virtio devices. It should be configurable, for example, if binding to an SRIOV device then it’ll need to be bound to a different dpdk driver. My first thought was to again make this a configuration in kuryr.conf. However my understanding is that configurations in kuryr.conf tend to be static, the dpdk-driver would always be the same for that VM. Do we want to cater for a scenario, for example, where a user may want one pod in the VM bound to a virtio device and you may want another pod bound to a SRIOV VF that has been attached to the VM?

A method of setting the driver dynamically could be to set the DPDK driver as one of the ARGS in cni.conf rather than setting it in kuryr.conf. Please let me know your thoughts.

Hi folks, so I've been playing around with configuring the DPDK driver dynamically. Using the CNI args from the cni/conf/10-kuryr.conf file is more difficult than I presumed, but I think it is doable. The CNI args are loaded within kuryr_kubernetes/cni/main.py and from here I found it difficult to make them available elsewhere in Kuryr without it becoming very "hacky".

I think a solution might be to register the CNI args from 10-kuryr.conf as options under the oslo_config, likely under their own group. This group could be made mutable, which should mean the opts can be reloaded without restarting Kuryr.

So, for example, if "dpdk_driver" is updated in 10-kuryr.conf then something like CONF.cni_args.dpdk_driver will be updated with the new value.

If we go with this then I think making the CNI args available via oslo_config should be a feature of it's own, certainly a separate commit.

What do you guys think? Am I on the right track? Am I over complicating it? Would having the CNI args available via oslo_config be useful elsewhere?
+1 for the second option.
I would vote for the second choice, to make it dynamic. It is also aligned with the discussions in k8s-net-sig regarding multiple networks support

I’d like some input on how to best implement this section of code. dpdk-devbind is what I’m using to unbind the virtio device from the kernel driver and bind it to the dpdk driver. It’s a python script usually located under /sbin/ on Ubuntu. I think it comes by default with Ubuntu images. The script is here: https://github.com/ceph/dpdk/blob/master/tools/dpdk-devbind.py

The issue is what if this script is not present on the users VM? They could be using a different distro, the script could be in a different location, etc. So I see a few options here.

OPTION 1 - Make the location of the script configurable in kuryr.conf so it’s up to the user to ensure the script is installed and to point kuryr to the script location. Additional option to include a bash script with Kuryr that downloads and installs devbind. Or maybe we just include instructions as part of Kuryr docs.

OPTION2 - Do we want to copy the necessary functions from dpdk-devbind script into this Kuryr binding driver? Then Kuryr will not depend on dpdk-devbind at all, it will be able to do the (un)binding itself.

.zuul.d/jobs.yaml.message: Why do you need these two new jobs instead of just adding their parents to the check queue? Is it because their parents do not include DIB in their required-projects list? Would it be better to include DIB in those jobs instead? Otherwise, the these two ironic jobs could pass in DIB gate but not in Ironic gate.
Yes, because of this. DIB is usually consumed from releases, similar to libraries, so I assumed it's better to get ironic against released DIB (so that we don't start relying on unreleased features).

.zuul.d/project.yaml.message: Note that continued CentOS 7 support is no longer a requirement starting from Ussuri. DIB may at some point drop it. Please consider this and evaluate how to best handle it in Ironic stable branches CI jobs prior to Ussuri (i.e. consume DIB from upper-constraints.txt from given branch instead of master).
I've realized that we do use DIB from upper-constraints in stable/train. Note that this, however, contradicts your previous recommendation of adding DIB to required-projects :)

Unless you want to start having stable branches, there are no way we can avoid this situation. Consuming DIB from upper-constraints.txt means that bugs can never be fixed (e.g. if an update to CentOS 7 breaks something in DIB).

My comment was about the change proposed in the depends-on patch [1] that you're adding DIB to the required-project list of a base job. However, I did not consider that that is on a branched project (unlike tempest plugin projects that are branchless) so the base job will not impact stable branch jobs because they are kept defined in separate branches from master.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/703585/1/zuul.d/ironic-python-agent-jobs.yaml@165
I'd rather see this job consistently passing for some time before adding it to the gate.

DIB has tests for CentOS 8 so we should be able to catch issues related to CentOS 8 with the existing jobs. You may, however, be referring to the recent breakage with the update to 8.1. That has been fixed and the CI jobs caught that too.

What I meant is that personally I believe no job should be added immediately to the gate regardless of the project.
Made non-voting for now. I do hope we can make it voting ASAP since it represents a very popular use case for DIB.
The reason it has been failing is the breakage of DIB with CentOS 8. I think it's useful for you to know it.

tools/deployment/airskiff/developer/100-.message:
It looks like this will always add to the end of the list, not only when localhost is found. That is fine, but this comment shouldn't contradict that.

It's also probably safe to delete localhost and not re-add it.

I am planning to add a check to look for 127.0.0.1, and update the /etc/resolv.conf only if it contains "nameserver 127.0.0.1" This was just a hack to test it.

Also, regarding adding 127.0.0.1 back in the list or not. I agree. Beacuse, there is a limit of 3 entries for the nameservers list, anything after the 3rd will be ignored anyways. We normally always have 1 entry for cluster-dns/coredns 10.96.0.10, and at least 2 enties for upstream google dns, or interanl dns.
based on this adding 127.0.0.1 to the end of the list will move it to at least the fourth place, which is equivalent to not adding it.

I was bit hesitant to remove the 127.0.0.1 entry all together, because I tried it for the openstack-helm-infra /etc/resolv.conf and the name resolution failed, causing all the gates fail. But, for treasuremap 127.0.0.1 doesn't seem to matter. I will not add it.
